title: Running `rails server` with missing or mis-spelled environments file silently hides the mistake
body:
### Steps to reproduce

```
rails new lol --minimal --skip-active-record
cd lol
cat << EOF > config/environments/staging.rb
require_relative "production"

Rails.application.configure do
end
EOF
RAILS_ENV=stage rails server
```

### Expected behavior

If I have a file `config/environments/staging.rb` and I accidentally try to run `RAILS_ENV=stage rails server` (note it is `stage` but the file is `staging`). I expect I will get an error.

### Actual behavior

It boots with no problem and no clear warning:

```
$ RAILS_ENV=stage rails server
=> Booting Puma
=> Rails 8.0.3 application starting in stage
=> Run `bin/rails server --help` for more startup options
config.eager_load is set to nil. Please update your config/environments/*.rb files accordingly:

  * development - set it to false
  * test - set it to false (unless you use a tool that preloads your test environment)
  * production - set it to true

Puma starting in single mode...
* Puma version: 7.0.4 ("Romantic Warrior")
* Ruby version: ruby 3.4.6 (2025-09-16 revision dbd83256b1) +YJIT +PRISM [arm64-darwin24]
*  Min threads: 3
*  Max threads: 3
*  Environment: stage
*          PID: 86318
* Listening on http://0.0.0.0:3000
Use Ctrl-C to stop
```

## Suggestion

> WARNING: You are using `RAILS_ENV=stage`, but no `config/environments/stage.rb` was found. Known environments:
>
> - test.rb
> - production.rb
> - development.rb
>
> If this is intentional, you can ignore this warning by setting `RAILS_IGNORE_MISSING_ENV=stage`

Related: We could also have `Rails.env.<environment>?`, also check for the existence of a specific file for proof that it's a valid environment. Otherwise, `Rails.env.staaging?` has the same problem (silent typo failure, hard to find).

### System configuration

**Rails version**: 8.0.3

**Ruby version**: 3.4.6
